title: Terrifying 70mph car chase that killed innocent mum-of-five in horror crash

A terrifying high speed chase that claimed the life of a mum-of-five was captured on multiple CCTV cameras before it came to its deadly conclusion.

Lewis Fisher, 21, was seen "smiling and laughing" and "was having a joke" during the high-speed pursuit moments before innocent Joanne Bailey-Collinge, 34, was killed.

Video of the chase released by Greater Manchester Police shows Fisher reaching speeds of about 70mph in his Mercedes C220 as he was chased by driver Joseph Pownall.

They travel through built-up areas at ridiculous speeds and on the wrong side of the road before the Mercedes ploughs into the oncoming Volkswagen Polo on April 20 - the day before Easter Sunday.

The fatal chase followed a row over a smashed window in Wigan, Greater Manchester, which had left Pownall "intent on revenge".

(Image: MEN Media)

Mrs Bailey-Collinge's husband, who was in the front passenger seat next to her, and her 13-year-old daughter, who was in the back, were both seriously injured.

Her four-year-old daughter suffered minor injuries.

Fisher, who did not have a driving licence and was uninsured, was found guilty on Tuesday of causing the death of by dangerous driving.

Pownall, 26, had already pleaded guilty to the same charge.

He was sentenced to 12 years in prison at Manchester Crown Court.

The court heard that on Pownall's Facebook page, a message had been posted stating: "You can lock the lock, but you can’t stop the clock."

Judge Richard Mansell QC said he accepted someone else had posted the message, which he described as 'insensitive to say the least', in Pownall's name.

(Image: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd)

(Image: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd)

The Judge told him: "By your senseless act of aggression you have brought unimaginable tragedy to bear on this family."

Witness Olga Larson told the trial that Fisher was "smiling and laughing" as he was chased by Pownall, who was driving a Volkswagen Amarok pickup truck.

Ms Larson, who was driving home when she saw the cars, told the jury: "(The Mercedes driver) was not looking ahead, he was looking in the rear mirror and smiling and laughing.

"I knew for a certainty that he was looking at the mirror with a big wide grin on his face and I know he was laughing.

(Image: Cavendish Press (Manchester) Ltd)

(Image: Manchester Evening News)

"He was having a joke, it was fun to him."

When he was arrested after the crash he claimed he was "frightened" and drove off as fast as he could to escape Pownall.

Nigel Edwards QC, defending, said his client also denied boasting of his driving in the pub and was genuinely remorseful for the "moment of madness".

The court also heard father-of-one Fisher, who has never had a driving licence, was also apologetic.

But prosecutors told the trial that the drivers had treated the chase as a "little game... with dreadful circumstances" and Fisher was "enjoying" the pursuit.

As the drivers reached speeds of about 70mph at a bend in the road, the Mercedes veered into the wrong lane and ploughed into a car being driven by the mum-of-five.

She later died of her injuries.

(Image: MEN Media)

The chase began after one of Fisher's friends threw a brick and smashed one of the truck's windows outside a pub at about 5.30pm.

The two vehicles sped through neighbourhood 30mph zones at around 70mph, the court heard.

Fisher was found guilty of causing death by dangerous driving, causing death while driving unlicensed, causing death by driving while uninsured, and two counts of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.

Pownall admitted causing death by dangerous driving and causing serious injury by dangerous driving.

Following sentencing, Mr Collinge said: "We all miss Joanne so much and it has been very difficult reliving the incident and everything that happened.

"She was the love of my life and such a great mum. We just can't imagine our lives without her.

"The people responsible for Joanne's death have left us with our own life sentence."
